poem:
The Disappearing Middle

In the white collars' shadow,  
figures blur—  
graduate daughter,  
doctor of the invisible  
spine—  
where averages grow  
thick as mist.

Earn more, earn less—  
where is the hand  
that steadies?  
Lost in the calculation of days,  
we search—  
discontent  
grains, slipping through  
pale fingers  
toward  
the ground.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Falling white-collar pay and the cost to society | Letters Gaby Hinsliff makes some very interesting points in her article (The death of the middle-class professional spells danger for Labour, 2 January). But as so often, averages hide a range of experience. I look at my own graduate daughters and their contemporaries. My eldest is 27 and a junior doctor, so she earns more than those average graduate salaries (looking at gross not hourly rates). But". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
